Flynn, and have questioned witnesses about whether he was secretly paid by the Turkish government during the final months of the presidential campaign, according to people close to the investigation.

headline: Psychic Saw a New Home in Her Future, Before Crossing Paths With Police
text: The woman known in her upscale Connecticut community as the Greenwich Psychic answered a reporter’s ring of the buzzer in Manhattan on Thursday and, clearly irritated, nonetheless offered a glimpse at the gift for which she gained repute.

headline: Richard Dudman, Reporter at Center of History’s Churn, Dies at 99
text: Richard Dudman, a much-traveled reporter for The St. Louis Post-Dispatch who spent more than a month in captivity in Cambodia after being ambushed by Vietcong fighters and later survived an assassination attempt after meeting the Cambodian dictator Pol Pot, died on Thursday in Blue Hill, Me. He was 99.

headline: How This U.S. Tech Giant Is Backing China’s Tech Ambitions
text: As the Chinese government develops drones, the American technology giant Qualcomm is helping. The same goes for artificial intelligence, mobile technology and supercomputers. Qualcomm is also working to help Chinese companies like Huawei break into overseas markets in support of China’s “go global” campaign to develop big multinational brands.

headline: Nebraska State Patrol Problems Go Beyond ‘Perverse’ Medical Exam, Report Finds
text: A lawsuit filed by a member of the Nebraska State Patrol contained a shocking allegation against the agency: A male doctor working for the patrol had instructed her to expose her genitalia during a pre-employment physical exam.

headline: Trump Defends McMaster Against Calls for His Firing
text: President Trump defended Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, his embattled national security adviser, on Friday in the face of a full-bore campaign by the nationalist wing of his political coalition accusing him of undermining the president’s agenda and calling for his dismissal.

headline: Gene Editing for ‘Designer Babies’? Highly Unlikely, Scientists Say
text: Now that science is a big step closer to being able to fiddle with the genes of a human embryo, is it time to panic? Could embryo editing spiral out of control, allowing parents to custom-order a baby with Lin-Manuel Miranda’s imagination or Usain Bolt’s speed?

headline: Let’s Make a Wall Deal
text: It’s been a busy time for border wall aficionados. Seems like every day there’s a new dramatic development:

headline: Pulling Back the Curtain on Poetry
text: Everybody knows that a finished piece of writing rarely springs, fully formed, from the author’s mind. But how does it get from there to here? The cover of this week’s Book Review features the marked-up draft of a poem by Eduardo C. Corral — one of a series of such annotated manuscripts, from six different poets, that anchor a special poetry-themed issue. I love seeing drafts for the same reason I love seeing artists’ sketches: because they show the mind at play, solving creative problems, and they illuminate the sometimes painstaking process behind the finished piece. They let us eavesdrop on a kind of dialogue or argument between the writer and the work itself. I have long been on the lookout for an opportunity to bring in-the-works drafts into the Book Review, and the poetry issue offered a perfect fit.

headline: Venezuela’s New Leaders Begin Their March Toward Total Control
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Members of President Nicolás Maduro’s governing party marched triumphantly into Venezuela’s Capitol building on Friday, calling to order a 545-member body with plans to rewrite the Constitution and consolidate their power over the nation.

headline: Donors, Fund-Raisers, Friends: Gaining Access to De Blasio’s City Hall
text: For Jona S. Rechnitz and Jeremiah Reichberg, giving money to Mayor Bill de Blasio’s political campaigns offered a backstage pass to city government. They exchanged friendly emails with the mayor and got access to high-level officials to discuss business they had with the city.

headline: Hometown Boy Doesn’t Make Good
text: It didn’t sit well with many in upstate New York when President Trump told them that they live in “an area that just isn’t working” and ought to move elsewhere, like maybe Wisconsin. “It’s O.K.,” he said in an interview with The Wall Street Journal. “Don’t worry about your house.”

headline: Yellow Fever Outbreak That Threatened Brazil’s Megacities Ends
text: An alarming outbreak of yellow fever that threatened Brazil early this year appears to be over, according to data released this week by the Pan American Health Organization.

headline: Regulators Investigating Ford Police Vehicles for Possible Exhaust Hazard
text: In February, police officers in Austin, Tex., began complaining of dizziness and headaches while driving Ford sport utility vehicles that are specially made for law enforcement use. City officials suspected the cause was carbon monoxide leaking from the exhaust system.

headline: Good Retirement, Sweet Prince
text: There are not many people who in their lifetime have had films made about them, had their image stamped onto a coin or had their obituary printed. But then not that many people have maintained an arduous work schedule in a highly visible job to the age of 96, as has Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh and consort of Queen Elizabeth II who retired this week. He has royally earned the right to rest (some would say so has his wife, but then she’s only 91).

headline: ‘We Do Not See Things as They Are’
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s not really a secret that we all see, feel, smell and hear things differently. If you have ever sat through a course in philosophy, you know that our perception of what is “real” is based not on what something actually is, but what we say it is. Which is always incredibly disappointing to a teenager who has come to college to discover the “real” world (“That’s it?! That’s all there is to it? Can I go now?”)

headline: No Sanctuary for the Immigration Lawyer
text: NEW HAVEN — Across two decades as an immigration lawyer practicing the quieter arts of saving clients from federal deportation, Glenn Formica never thought highly of the tactic of seeking refuge in a church, where law enforcement is hesitant to intrude. He was skeptical of the sanctuary approach, and the ephemeral hopes he thought it generated in trying to shield undocumented immigrants in dramatic standoffs with authorities.

headline: Why Trump Supporters Distrust Immigration and Diversity
text: President Trump’s support for a proposal from Senators Tom Cotton and David Perdue that slashes legal immigration and reports about the Justice Department’s renewed interests in scrutinizing college affirmative action programs should come as no surprise. Mr. Trump is catering to his largely middle-aged, white, middle- and working-class base. That’s what politicians do.

headline: What Was Australia Doing in Vietnam?
text: In July 1967 President Lyndon B. Johnson sent two of his principal advisers, Clark Clifford and Gen. Maxwell Taylor, to Australia and New Zealand with an urgent mission. Protests were raging in American streets and on university campuses. Hawks and doves were battling in Washington. Defense Secretary Robert McNamara was heading toward resignation, an admission that his Vietnam policy had failed.

headline: Fred Leighton, a Jeweler Who Made Stars Glitter, Dies at 85
text: Fred Leighton, a so-called jeweler to the stars whose antique jewelry became coveted accessories for actresses like Nicole Kidman and Lupita Nyong’o when they walked the red carpet of the Academy Awards, died on July 26 in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Wells Fargo May Have Found More Fake Accounts Created by Employees
text: Wells Fargo, already struggling to rebuild its reputation after a scandal over the creation of fraudulent bank accounts, signaled on Friday that it could have more bad news coming.

headline: Growing Pains and Struggling Offense Sink the Yankees in Cleveland
text: CLEVELAND — The talent the young Yankees flash can be seductive, making it easy to forget that there is still a refinement process that comes with it. The rough edges to a prospect’s game — even the ones that are not readily apparent — need time to be smoothed out.

headline: On Raucous Night in Queens, Mets Are an Afterthought
text: If the Mets were hoping for a gentle transition for Amed Rosario, the jewel of their farm system, into the pressure cooker of New York baseball, they could have hardly picked a better night for his Citi Field debut.

headline: Nissan Workers in Mississippi Reject Union Bid by U.A.W.
text: In a test of labor’s ability to expand its reach in the South, workers at a Nissan plant in Mississippi have overwhelmingly rejected a bid to unionize.

headline: Mo Farah Wins 10,000 at Worlds Before Home Crowd
text: Mo Farah launched the world championships in scintillating fashion Friday with another consummate 10,000-meter victory that further embellished his claim to being the greatest distance racer. With 55,000 of his home fans roaring their support at London Stadium, Farah, 34, of Britain sprinted away with a gold medal in a global track final for a 10th consecutive time.

headline: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Icarus’ and ‘Rachel Getting Married’
text: In “Icarus,” Bryan Fogel sets out to test doping in cycling and ends up embroiled in an international scandal. And the movie “Rachel Getting Married,” Jonathan Demme’s loving tale of family dysfunction, comes to Hulu.

headline: Republican Senator Is on a Mission to Rescue the Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Lamar Alexander voted to repeal the Affordable Care Act numerous times and wanted it gone. Now he is trying to save it — at least for the moment.

headline: Britain Turns to Chinese Textbooks to Improve Its Math Scores
text: BEIJING — Educators around the world were stunned when students in Shanghai came first in their international standardized testing debut, in 2010, besting their counterparts in dozens of countries in what some called a Sputnik-like moment.

headline: Canada Letter: Spurning Silicon Valley and Rock’s Native Roots
text: When it comes to technology, Canada — as well as Mexico and China — is expanding, at the expense of the United States. That’s what Kirk Semple, one of my colleagues based in Mexico, and I found out and wrote about recently.

headline: A San Francisco Hotel Wired for a Tech Central Crowd
text: From $279.

headline: ‘I’m Still Overweight, but Much Happier and Healthier’
text: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

headline: A Ride for the Red Planet
text: Step inside this Mars rover concept vehicle created as part of the Kennedy Space Center’s “Summer of Mars” campaign to celebrate advances in exploration of the planet.

headline: In Weary Wisconsin Town, a Billionaire-Fueled Revival
text: BELOIT, Wis. — When Diane Hendricks sees something she doesn’t like here, she buys it.

headline: In Afghanistan, U.S. Exits, and Iran Comes In
text: FARAH, Afghanistan — A police officer guarding the outskirts of this city remembers the call from his commander, warning that hundreds of Taliban fighters were headed his way.

headline: On Irish Border, Worries That ‘Brexit’ Will Undo a Hard-Won Peace
text: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland — Crossing the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic used to involve delays, checkpoints, bureaucratic harassment and the lurking threat of violence. That it’s now virtually seamless — that you can drive across without even knowing it — feels close to miraculous.

headline: A Flawed Asylum System in Mexico, Strained Further by U.S. Changes
text: MEXICO CITY — As the Trump administration pushes forward with its plans to harden the southwest border, Mexico has found itself under pressure to take in an increasing number of asylum seekers making their way north from Central America, many of them fleeing  gang violence.

headline: North Korean Defector, ‘Treated Like Dirt’ in South, Fights to Return
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Divorced and out of money, Kwon Chol-nam fled North Korea for China in 2014 by wading across a river border at night and then crawling over a barbed-wire fence. After a perilous trek that included walking through a jungle in Laos, he reached Thailand, where he was allowed to fly to South Korea to start a new life.

headline: For a Couple a Combined 171 Years Old, a Young Love
text: Dr. John Vincent Abbott Jr. and Dr. E. Gerald Dabbs were married Aug. 5 in the ballroom of Dr. Abbott’s home in Ridgefield, Conn. Patricia E. Henry, a retired State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn, officiated.

headline: Firming Up Tentative Plans
text: Carla Nasr and Levi Watson Azia Quaintance were married Aug. 5 at Jefferson Market Garden in Manhattan. Erin E. Reitz, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries, officiated.

headline: Losing an Auction Resulted in a Win
text: Jessica Hope Morganoff and Gideon Yaacov Sims were married on Aug. 5 at Battery Gardens in New York. Cantor Neil A. Berris led the ceremony.

headline: Of Mice and Men Like Mick Jagger: A Literary Scion Tells All
text: One might reasonably assume that Natasha Fraser-Cavassoni, the youngest daughter of the English historian and novelist Lady Antonia Fraser and the late politician Sir Hugh Fraser, had a posh upbringing. Private schools. Pretty clothes. A retreat in Scotland.

headline: Jeannette Walls Settles Down Far From the Noise of New York
text: ORANGE, Va. — Early in the “The Glass Castle,” the movie based on Jeannette Walls’s memoir of growing up destitute, Rex Walls sidles up to his little girl, who lies burned and bandaged in a hospital bed.

headline: A Hollywood Party Planner Who Isn’t Instagram-Obsessed
text: LOS ANGELES — As the evening sky faded to bluish white, Yifat Oren, 45, surveyed her handiwork. “Don’t light the candles just yet,” the event producer said to one of her assistants. “We need to wait for the wind to die down.” Another assistant was sent to fetch the seating chart for a quick rearrangement.

headline: SoHo’s New Geeks
text: We wanted to see where stylish New York teenagers were gravitating. We found that just as music and fashion brought young people together in the past, streetwear and skater brands are bringing them together today.

headline: George Saunders on the Price of Dreams
text: How does anyone afford to have children? That’s a question the Sugars receive in this week’s episode from a woman who calls herself Broke Potential Mother.

headline: In a Swimmer’s Two-Year Quest, a Final 21-Mile Challenge
text: Antonio Argüelles, 58, rose near dawn Thursday hoping for good fortune.

headline: Singapore Orders Expulsion of American Academic
text: BANGKOK — Singapore has ordered the expulsion of a noted American academic for what it said was his covert effort to influence Singapore’s foreign policy on behalf of an unnamed foreign government.

headline: Female Lawmaker in Pakistan Accuses Imran Khan of ‘Inappropriate’ Texts. Abuse Follows.
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — When a Pakistani lawmaker said this past week that she had received “inappropriate text messages” from a male colleague, she was met with a wave of vitriol on social media.

headline: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: A Snap and Google Tie-Up?
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Can a Stroller Be Sent to the Back Door?
text: Q. About a month ago, my husband and I bought a co-op in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. Several times a day, we put our baby in a stroller and leave the building through the front door. As we returned home through that door recently, a person, who we believe works for the managing agent, told us that strollers must use a back entrance. An avid rule follower, I reread the resident handbook and found no rule about this. If a rule is not written, must it be followed?

headline: Racial Violence on the Screen
text: In the thick of “Detroit,” a new film by Kathryn Bigelow about the uprising in that city — my native city — 50 years ago, a white cop kills a black man. His partner then asks a witness, a black man, what he saw. The witness says he saw nothing. The partner puts the same question to another witness, a black teen, who refuses to play along.

headline: Texts on a Plane About Child Molestation Lead to Two Arrests
text: On a flight from Seattle to San Jose, Calif., on Monday, a woman caught a glimpse of some text messages that alarmed her.

headline: Being a Refugee Isn’t a Fashion Statement
text: It’s August in New York — a time when arriving to work from the subway and not looking like a drowned rat is a sartorial victory. What should working women wear to beat the heat? Linen, perhaps a romper. Or you could don the Refugee Dress.

headline: Republican Shadow Campaign for 2020 Takes Shape as Trump Doubts Grow
text: WASHINGTON — Senators Tom Cotton and Ben Sasse have already been to Iowa this year, Gov. John Kasich is eyeing a return visit to New Hampshire, and Mike Pence’s schedule is so full of political events that Republicans joke that he is acting more like a second-term vice president hoping to clear the field than a No. 2 sworn in a little over six months ago.

headline: Recipe for a Run: Add Bullpen Muscle
text: Kenley Jansen was asleep on the Los Angeles Dodgers’ charter plane on Monday when David Vassegh, the team’s radio beat reporter, awoke him with news: The Dodgers had acquired Yu Darvish, an All-Star starting pitcher, in a trade with the Texas Rangers. Jansen, the Dodgers’ closer, had a curious reaction.

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Usually, I can make my way into an acrostic by finding some gimmes, or answers that I know right off the bat. There are always a few of them, although the exact number depends on the puzzle itself. From there, I try to toggle between filling in the words in the grid and solving the clues.

headline: U.A.W. Accuses Nissan of ‘Scare Tactics’ as Workers Reject Union Bid
text: In a test of labor’s ability to expand its reach in the South, workers at a Nissan plant in Mississippi overwhelmingly rejected a bid to unionize, an election that the union quickly criticized.

headline: Pakistan’s Ousted Leader Criticizes Court Ruling and Plans Public Rally
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s ousted prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, sharply criticized the Supreme Court verdict that forced him to step down last week and said he was planning a big rally in his hometown, Lahore, to galvanize public support for his political party and his future.

headline: All Eyes Are on Tillerson and North Korean Counterpart at Asean Meeting
text: MANILA — Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson will for the first time on Sunday be in the same room with his North Korean counterpart, and much of the world will be watching for whether the two even acknowledge each other.

headline: Affirmative Action Policies Evolve, Achieving Their Own Diversity
text: Just a year ago, after the Supreme Court rejected a challenge to the University of Texas at Austin’s admissions program by a single swing vote, the question seemed to be edging, at last, toward an answer: Colleges could, the justices ruled, consider race when deciding whom to let through their gates.

headline: Search Is Suspended for 3 Missing Marines Off Australia
text: Officials have suspended the search for three missing United States Marines after an MV-22 Osprey, a hybrid aircraft, entered the water off the eastern coast of Australia around 4 p.m. local time on Saturday.

headline: Bobby Sticks It to Trump
text: WASHINGTON — As we contemplate crime and punishment in the Trump circle, it should be noted that our Russia-besotted president does share some traits with Dostoyevsky’s spiraling protagonist, Rodion Raskolnikov.

headline: An Elusive Immigration Compromise
text: The last time Gallup asked Americans if they thought immigration to the United States should increase or decrease, 35 percent chose a decrease, 24 percent an increase, and 38 percent preferred the present rate. Support for increasing immigration has been rising for a decade, but it remains relatively low. To the extent that there is a middle-ground position, it is for something like the status quo.

headline: When Will the Tech Bubble Burst?
text: At the height of a market mania in 1967, the author George Goodman captured the mood perfectly, comparing it to a surreal party that ends only when “black horsemen” burst through the doors and cut down all the revelers who remain. “Those who leave early are saved, but the ball is so splendid no one wants to leave while there is still time. So everybody keeps asking — what time is it? But none of the clocks have hands.”

headline: What’s the Deal, Mr. Trump?
text: President Trump promised he’d make so many great deals that we’d all get “tired of winning.” He’s certainly left Americans feeling worn out, but not because of any transactional whirlwind.

headline: As Others Pack, Some Millennials Commit to Puerto Rico
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Two young graduates from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology did the unthinkable last summer: They quit enviable jobs in New York and moved back to beleaguered Puerto Rico, bringing their plan for a start-up with them.

headline: The Policies of White Resentment
text: White resentment put Donald Trump in the White House. And there is every indication that it will keep him there, especially as he continues to transform that seething, irrational fear about an increasingly diverse America into policies that feed his supporters’ worst racial anxieties.

headline: Hire Women Your Mom’s Age
text: There’s something haywire about how women are expected to crunch our most celebrated achievements into a timetable that frequently lasts fewer than 20 years. Find a partner. Raise some chicks. Zoom to the top of your field. Check each box by 50.

headline: Is Trump’s Turmoil Slowing Economic Growth?
text: At the end of last month, the International Monetary Fund downgraded its forecast for economic growth in the United States. Where the I.M.F. previously predicted the economy would grow at a rate of 2.3 percent in 2017 and 2.5 percent in 2018, it now expects 2.1 percent growth in both years.

headline: Vladimir Putin’s Summer Vacation: A Siberia Scrapbook
text: What did President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia do on his summer vacation?

headline: Should I Help My Patients Die?
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — I WAS leafing through a patient’s chart last year when a colleague tapped me on the shoulder. “I have a patient who is asking about the End of Life Option Act,” he said in a low voice. “Can we even do that here?”

headline: Venezuela’s Ousted Attorney General Retreats on a Motorbike
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Venezuela’s dissident attorney general sped away from her headquarters on a motorbike on Saturday as she was being ousted by the country’s new all-powerful assembly, which moved toward a swift consolidation of its power.

headline: A Feminist Defense of Bridezillas
text: For many of the thousands of American weddings that have taken place so far this summer, there have been two unspoken requirements: 1) that the events be stunning, awe-inspiring, love-filled, unique and fun all at once, and 2) that they appear to have occurred miraculously, with zero effort or emotional output on the part of the bride.

headline: The 30-Something’s Guide to Real Estate
text: LINCOLN, NEB. — My parents threw me a surprise party when I graduated from college. I was the first in my family to do so, and it was, in many ways, a party for all of us. They rented a banquet hall, invited everyone they felt had played a key part in my arriving at that moment — and told me we were going to a cousin’s baby shower. Shortly after everyone yelled “surprise,” my dad took the microphone and started the festivities by introducing one of the few white American families there.

headline: U.N. Security Council Imposes Punishing New Sanctions on North Korea
text: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council on Saturday unanimously adopted a resolution to impose the most punishing sanctions yet against North Korea over its repeated defiance of a ban on testing missiles and nuclear bombs.

headline: Fox News Suspends Eric Bolling After Report of Lewd Text Messages
text: Fox News suspended Eric Bolling, a longtime host at the network, on Saturday pending an investigation into reports that he sent lewd photographs to three female colleagues via text message.

headline: Pulling Back on the Barbaric Use of Solitary Confinement
text: The Justice Department took a farsighted step last year when it banned the use of solitary confinement for young people in federal prisons. The decision — based on research showing that isolation promotes mental illness and self-harm — followed the widely publicized suicide of Kalief Browder, a young man who had been unjustly accused of a minor crime and sent to New York’s infamous Rikers Island jail complex, where he spent two traumatic years in solitary confinement.

headline: Minnesota Mosque Hit by Early-Morning Explosion
text: An early-morning blast rocked the Dar Al Farooq mosque in Bloomington, Minn., on Saturday, as worshipers had just begun to gather inside for morning prayers.

headline: Trump’s Travel Ban Means Hope for Ammar’s Family
text: With almost no refugees arriving, a sponsor offers to help those already here.

headline: Usain Bolt, in a Narrow Defeat, Leaves Behind a Yawning Chasm
text: LONDON — The moment and the crowd of 55,900 at London Stadium were his, and Usain Bolt was inches from a clean getaway.

headline: They’re Building a Trump-Centric Movement. But Don’t Call It Trumpism.
text: GLENDORA, Calif. — They’re the first to admit that trying to reorient conservatism and the Republican Party around a president who does not consider himself much of a conservative or a Republican is a bit of a riddle.

headline: Anchors Away!
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — It doesn’t happen often, but sometimes the stars align in my job and I am able to metaphorically and completely accidentally injure two birds with one stone. Today is one of those days.

headline: Judge Drops Rape Case Against U.S.C. Student, Citing Video Evidence
text: In the early hours of April 1, neither student at the University of Southern California knew what the other had had to drink. An Uber was called, and the male student was seen on video following the female student into her dorm, where they had sex.

headline: Kidnappers Plotted to Sell British Model Online, Italian Police Say
text: A Polish citizen has been charged with kidnapping a 20-year-old British model in what the Italian authorities said Saturday was part of a scheme to sell the woman on a pornography website.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Risking Death, He Fled North Korea. Now He’s Begging to Return.
text: “You have to ride a horse to know whether it’s the right mount for you. I have tried, and the South is not for me.”

headline: Corrections: August 6, 2017
text: NATIONAL

headline: After Powerful Start, Mets Drop Their Third Straight
text: This is the difference between a good, and possibly great, baseball team, and an unquestionably bad one: Six times, the Mets have played the Los Angeles Dodgers this season. Six times, the Mets have lost. The combined score of those games, including Saturday’s 7-4 Dodgers victory at Citi Field, is 49-15. And in those six games, the Dodgers have hit 23 home runs.

headline: Aroldis Chapman Escapes an Eerily Familiar Tight Spot in Yankees’ Victory
text: CLEVELAND — Rajai Davis may be long gone, but for Yankees closer Aroldis Chapman, the ghost of Davis was present and accounted for here Saturday night.

headline: Neymar Watches as P.S.G. Wins Its Opener
text: With fireworks exploding around him, Neymar emerged onto the field to present fans in Paris with the sight they had been expecting: the world’s most expensive player in a Paris St.-Germain uniform.

headline: Melissa Milich, Brian Bush
text: Melissa Brooke Milich and Brian Devereaux Bush were married Aug. 5 at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Rabbi Lisa Rubin officiated.

headline: Michelle Arbour, Ryan Scoggins
text: Michelle Arbour and Dr. Ryan Hoffman Scoggins were married Aug. 5 in Oakdale, N.Y. The Hon. Eileen Rakower, a justice of the Supreme Court in New York, officiated at the Bourne Mansion.

headline: Rebecca Mann, James Platts
text: Rebecca Mann and James Thayer Platts were married Aug. 5 at Ray’s Boathouse in Seattle. Bradley L. Tytel, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Natalie Gontcharova, Nicholas Carbone
text: Natalie Gontcharova and Nicholas Andrew Carbone were married Aug. 5 at the Meridian House, a mansion in Washington. The Very Rev. David B. Lett, a priest with the Old Catholic Diocese of New Jersey, officiated.

headline: Alison Macbeth, Daniel Cook
text: Alison Carol Macbeth and Daniel David Cook were married Aug. 4. The Rev. Egill Hallgrimsson, a Lutheran pastor, officiated at the Budir Church in Budir, a hamlet on the Snaefellsnes Peninsula in Iceland.

headline: Charles Sellew, David Fiocco
text: Charles Samuel Sellew and David Andrew Fiocco were married Aug. 5 at the Mill City Museum in Minneapolis. The Rev. Jane McBride, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

headline: Jessie Cohan, Jared LeBoff
text: Jessie Krane Cohan, a daughter of Cheryl L. Krane of Lake Oswego, Ore., and Robert D. Cohan of Newton, Mass., was married Aug. 5 to Jared Benjamin LeBoff, a son of Shelley F. LeBoff and Jay M. LeBoff of Beverly Hills, Calif. Larry Sanitsky, a cousin of the groom and a Universal Life minister, officiated at the home of the groom’s parents.

headline: Lindsay Thomson, Samuel Brill
text: Lindsay Sanders Thomson and Samuel Malcolm Brill were married Aug. 5 at the bride’s family home in South Londonderry, Vt. Bharat Ayyar, a friend of the couple, received permission from the Vermont secretary of state to officiate.

headline: Amy Schwartz, Jonathan Klein
text: Amy Lynn Schwartz and Jonathan David Klein were married Aug. 5 at the Memorial Art Gallery in Rochester. Rabbi Mark Shulman officiated.

headline: Alyson Maugeri, Jordan Albert
text: Alyson Isadora Maugeri and Jordan Harris Petersen Albert were married Aug. 4. Lauren M. Seber, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Nassau Inn in Princeton, N.J.

headline: Rina Pal, Jan Götzen
text: Rina Pal and Jan Mirco Götzen were married Aug. 5 at the Faculty Club at the University of California, Berkeley. The Rev. Bruce O’Neill, an Episcopal priest, officiated at a German Protestant ceremony, which followed a Bengali Hindu ceremony led by Arabinda Chakrabarti, a Hindu priest.

headline: Caroline Peck, Robert Love
text: Caroline Lindsay Peck, a daughter of Linda M. Peck and Staunton Peck of Summit, N.J., was married Aug. 5 to Robert Henry Love, a son of Joanne E. Love of Bernardsville, N.J., and James R. Love of New York. The Rev. Craig Swan, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in Narragansett, R.I., at St. Peter’s by-the-Sea, where he is the rector.

headline: Sarah Wallace, Ian Schwartz
text: Sarah Rose Wallace and Ian Gary Schwartz are to be married Aug. 6 in Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Jesse M. Olitzky is to officiate at the Beverly Hills Hotel.

headline: Liadan Donnelly, Aaron Plavnick
text: Liadan Elizabeth Donnelly and Aaron Daniel Plavnick were married Aug. 5 at the Columbus Park Refectory in Chicago. The officiant was Lt. Cmdr. Keith D. Plavnick of the United States Navy, the groom’s father, who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries.

headline: Ashley Graf, Jonathan Spagnola
text: Ashley Gainer Graf and Dr. Jonathan Frederick Spagnola were married on Aug. 5 in New Hope, Pa. The Rev. Samuel Massengill, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Hotel du Village, an event space.

headline: Ariel Herm, Adam Koshkin
text: Ariel Rebecca Herm and Adam Levin Koshkin were married on Aug. 5 at the Squaw Valley resort in Olympic Valley, Calif. Cameron L. Scherer, a friend of the couple who introduced them, became an American Marriage Ministries minister to officiate.

headline: Jessica Sleater, Jorge Montalvo
text: Jessica June Sleater and Jorge Isaac Montalvo were married Aug. 4 in Manhattan. Msgr. Kevin Sullivan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of the Rosary.

headline: Amber Katherine, Kimberly Russo
text: Amber L. Katherine and Kimberly Kathryn Russo are to be married Aug. 6. Richard Amir Tahvildaran-Jesswein, a friend who is a minister of the First Nation Church, is to officiate on the beach in Santa Monica, Calif. Derek Hogen Dieter, a Zen Buddhist priest, will take part in the ceremony.

headline: Caroline Corbett, Nicholas Sizer
text: Caroline Alicia Corbett and Nicholas Budd Sizer were married July 31 at the Marriage Bureau in Manhattan. Angel L. Lopez, a staff member in the New York City Clerk’s Office, officiated.

headline: Lara Crystal, Robert Saliterman
text: Lara Elizabeth Crystal and Robert Warren Saliterman were married Aug. 5. Cantor Bruce L. Ruben officiated at the Pierre, the New York hotel.

headline: Justine Anania, J.D. Gross
text: Justine Elizabeth Anania and Jeremy David Gross were married Aug. 5 in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Rabbi Nicole Auerbach officiated at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

headline: Allison Zeilinger, Taylor Greason
text: Allison Eileen Zeilinger and Taylor Kosa Greason were married Aug. 5 in Vail, Colo. The Rev. Jose Maria Quera, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Vail Chapel.

headline: Christiana Stephenson, Matthew Aks
text: Christiana Elizabeth Stephenson and Matthew Louis Aks were married Aug. 5 in Manning Chapel at Brown University in Providence, R.I. The Rev. Jamie P. Washam, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Kathleen Ashby, Lukas Kohoutek
text: Kathleen Victoria Ashby and Lukas Kohoutek were married Aug. 5 at the Church of St. Wenceslas in Mikulov, Czech Republic. The Rev. Oldrich Chocholac, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Anja Crowder, Peter Morice
text: Anja Ramme Crowder and Peter Gunther Alexander Morice were married Aug. 5 in Combourg, France. Christiane Guervilly, the mayor of Erquy, France, officiated, with the Rev. Gareth Randall, an Anglican priest, leading a spiritual ceremony at the Château du Grand Val.

headline: Joelle Silverman, Vladyslav Golyk
text: Joelle Marisa Silverman and Vladyslav Alexander Golyk are to be married Aug. 6 at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Rabbi Paula Mack Drill is to officiate.

headline: Ann Wright, Manish Engineer
text: Ann Carolyn Wright and Manish Shirish Engineer were married Aug. 5 at the McDonald Observatory in Fort Davis, Tex. Judge Bryant Culpepper, a family court judge in Perry, Ga., officiated. Earlier in the day, Krishnaswamy Bhattar, a Hindu priest, led a ceremony that incorporated Hindu wedding traditions at the Capri, an event space in Marfa, Tex.

headline: Lauren Haffer, Jonathan Birnbaum
text: Lauren Paige Haffer and Jonathan Adam Birnbaum are to be married Aug. 6 in Farmingdale, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Klayman is to officiate at the Carlyle on the Green, an event space.

headline: Patricia Lee, David Martorana
text: Patricia Lee, the daughter of Phoebe Y. Lee and Chao L. Lee of Fullerton, Calif., was married Aug. 5 to David Michael Martorana, the son of Roberta Martorana of Richmond, Va., and Ronald K. K. Sakimura of Honolulu. Alexandra M. Armstrong, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Rimsha Ahmed, Michael Santos
text: Dr. Rimsha Ahmed and Dr. Michael Arthur Santos were married Aug. 5 at the Rodin Museum in Philadelphia. Imam Hamad A. Chebli, a Muslim cleric, officiated.

headline: Melissa Kovner, Nicholas Levine
text: Melissa Mae Kovner and Nicholas Brian Levine were married Aug. 5, at Allaire Studios at Glen Tonche in Shokan, N.Y., a 22-acre estate built in 1928 by Raymond Pitcairn and used in recent years as a music recording studio. Richard Vogel, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: Kailan Sierra-Davidson, Alexander Loomis
text: Kailan Alysabeth Sierra-Davidson and Alexander Hale Loomis were married Aug. 5. The Rev. Gail W. Wright, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at David’s Folly Farm in Brooksville, Me.

headline: Khendi White, Adebanjo Solaru
text: Dr. Khendi Tahira White and Adebanjo Oluwafolayimika Solaru are to be married Aug. 6 at the Ariel International Center in Cleveland. The Rev. Larry Green, a Baptist minister, is to officiate.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Game of Thrones’ and ‘Sharknado 5: Global Swarming’
text: Emilia Clarke scraps a failing plan to conquer her enemies in “Game of Thrones.” And Ian Ziering and Tara Reid’s fight against sharks gets personal.

headline: When Foreign Companies Are Making, Not Killing, U.S. Jobs
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — At the airport here, there is a reminder to travelers of the jobs that global trade can bring. A shiny 2017 Volkswagen Passat is stationed near the entryway and labeled: “Designed in Germany. Built in Chattanooga.”

headline: Transgender African-Americans’ Open Wound: ‘We’re Considered a Joke’
text: When Elle Hearns watched the video clip someone had sent to her on social media, it really stung.

headline: Let Forest Fires Burn? What the Black-Backed Woodpecker Knows
text: BUCK MEADOWS, Calif. — With long strides, Chad T. Hanson plunged into a burned-out forest, his boots kicking up powdery ash. Blackened, lifeless trees stretched toward an azure sky.

headline: Mueller, Trump, Russia: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: A Communist Icon Toppled in Ukraine Is Restored. In England.
text: MANCHESTER, England — After 147 years, Friedrich Engels is back in town. Statues of Engels, Karl Marx’s collaborator, may have been ripped down all over the former communist world, but he has returned here, to the city that made him famous.

headline: The Atomic Bombing of Hiroshima
text: Through modeling and mapping technologies, witness from above what happened in Hiroshima, Japan on Aug. 6, 1945.

headline: Chinese Tourists Arrested Over Nazi Salutes
text: BERLIN — Like millions of visitors to Germany each year, two Chinese tourists made their way this weekend to the Reichstag, seat of the lower house of Parliament, where they snapped photos of themselves outside the historic building.

headline: Tillerson Hails U.N. Sanctions, as Chinese Minister Rebukes North Korea at Asean Meeting
text: MANILA — A day after the United Nations Security Council passed its toughest sanctions against North Korea, Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson met with his South Korean and Chinese counterparts here in hopes of ratcheting up pressure on Pyongyang.

headline: Detroit’s Mayoral Election Is a Test of Recovery and Legacy
text: DETROIT — Coleman A. Young II was settling into a diner booth with a mug of hot chocolate heaped with whipped cream when a stranger approached. “I adored your father, and I hope you’re just like him,” she said. Hours later, as Mr. Young rode in a car along a neighborhood street, someone called out, “I voted for your dad, man!” And when he stood before residents of an apartment complex, a woman rose to recount her memories of Mr. Young’s father, Coleman A. Young, Detroit’s first black mayor. “He made a whole lot of difference in this city,” she said.

headline: Where Were You During the Great American Eclipse of 2017?
text: As an eerie midday twilight settled over Baker, Ore., on June 8, 1918, the hearts of a group of astronomers began to sink. Clouds became dense, and their chance to watch the sun wink out was in jeopardy.

headline: Bill de Blasio Will Push for Tax on Wealthy to Fix Subway
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio plans to push for a tax on wealthy New Yorkers to pay for improvements needed to address the crisis engulfing New York City’s subway, city officials said on Sunday.

headline: An Ice Cream Maker’s Latest Recipe: Saving the Local School
text: MARKDALE, Ontario — Like hundreds of small towns in Ontario, Markdale got the bad news from the provincial government last year: Its elementary school would have to close, a victim of cost-cutting.

headline: Struggling to Survive, Congregations Look to Sell Houses of Worship
text: At first glance, the preservation battle over the nearly century-old synagogue on a tree-lined block of West 93rd Street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan looks familiar, even tired. One group wants to save the stately granite building, emphasizing its history, neoclassical architecture and towering stained glass windows. Another group wants to turn it into a high-rise condominium.

headline: Obama-Era Fight Over Coal Royalties Turns Into Trump-Era Alliance
text: The coal industry sued, protested and lobbied to block a rule increasing royalties for mining coal on federal land. Then President Trump was elected, and the rule was suspended. The inside story is told in documents collected by The New York Times

headline: An Election Reverses Federal Coal Policy
text: The Trump administration killed an Obama-era ban on new federal coal leases. Here are the documents.

headline: Under Trump, Coal Mining Gets New Life on U.S. Lands
text: DECKER, Mont. — The Trump administration is wading into one of the oldest and most contentious debates in the West by encouraging more coal mining on lands owned by the federal government. It is part of an aggressive push to both invigorate the struggling American coal industry and more broadly exploit commercial opportunities on public lands.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Good morning. Elmore Leonard once cautioned against the use of weather to open a piece of writing. “The reader is apt to leaf ahead looking for people,” he said. (He allowed an exception: Barry Lopez, and that’s totally right. Read “Arctic Dreams,” and you’ll see why.) But Leonard never spent time on my block, this time of year, in early morning warmth with just a riffle of breeze coming down the cobblestones from the water, soft air scented with diesel and salt that flutters the leaves of the Callery pear trees, beneath a bluebird sky.

headline: Political Donors Put Their Money Where the Memes Are
text: Imagine you’re a millionaire or billionaire with strong political views and a desire to spread those views to the masses. Do you start a think tank in Washington? Funnel millions to a shadowy “super PAC”? Bankroll the campaign of an up-and-coming politician?

headline: Review: Lady Gaga, the Flashy Provocateur, Battles Lady Gaga, the Raw Voice
text: TACOMA, Wash. — Lady Gaga introduced her performance of “Joanne” at the Tacoma Dome here on Saturday night with a long disquisition on what she called “generational grief” and how it shaped this song, the title track from her latest album. She dedicated the performance to people who have been affected by a pain so long-running they can’t remember a time before it, and let them know that they were not alone.

headline: Military Base Attacked in Venezuela as Video Calls for Rebellion
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Armed men in military uniforms and camouflage released a video early Sunday morning calling for Venezuelans to rebel against President Nicolás Maduro after his party established an all-powerful assembly meant to secure its grip over the country.

headline: Japan Marks Hiroshima Anniversary, With North Korea on Its Mind
text: TOKYO — Every year in early August, Japanese politicians and peace activists converge on Hiroshima to commemorate the day when the city was devastated by an American atomic bomb. In the famous peace park, the horrors of World War II are vividly recounted. Speakers of all political stripes repeat Japan’s postwar mantra: “Never again.”

headline: How a Son of Sam Detective Realized ‘This Has Got to Be the Guy’
text: James Justus remembers hanging up the telephone convinced that he had something.

headline: Diplomats Question Tactics of Tillerson, the Executive Turned Secretary of State
text: WASHINGTON — Several times a week the State Department sends a greeting to a foreign country on the occasion of its national day. By tradition, the salutations have been written by low-level diplomats and routinely approved by their superiors.

headline: For Dodgers Star Justin Turner, the Mets’ Rejection Still Motivates
text: There are telephone calls that stick in the mind forever, critical conversations at pivotal moments in life. For Justin Turner, one of those calls came as he was getting into his car at his Los Angeles home on Dec. 2, 2013.

headline: ‘This Is Us’ Loses Emmy Nomination for Costumes
text: When the 2017 Emmy nominations were announced in June, NBC’s “This Is Us” represented a rare bright spot for network television. The soapy family series earned 11 nominations, including one for best drama — the first time in six years that an ABC, CBS, Fox or NBC drama was nominated in that category.

headline: ‘Detroit’ Suffers Box-Office Setback as ‘Dark Tower’ Is No. 1
text: LOS ANGELES — Kathryn Bigelow’s well-reviewed “Detroit” arrived to about $7.3 million in North American ticket sales over the weekend, a limp result for a wide-release movie that cost at least $55 million to make and market.

headline: A New Adrienne Kennedy Play Will Be Staged Next Year
text: Adrienne Kennedy, whose surrealism-tinged dramas have addressed race and violence in American society since the 1960s, will have a new play, her first in nine years, as part of the coming season at Theater for a New Audience.

headline: Mike Pence Rejects Report That He Is Positioning for 2020
text: Vice President Mike Pence declared his loyalty to President Trump on Sunday and denounced a New York Times article suggesting that he was positioning himself to run for president in 2020 if Mr. Trump does not seek a second term.

headline: 4 Easy(ish) Ways to Save a Few Extra Bucks This Week
text: Welcome to the Smarter Living newsletter. Editor Tim Herrera emails readers once a week with tips and advice for living a better, more fulfilling life. Sign up here to get it in your inbox every Monday morning.

headline: Europe Swelters Under a Heat Wave Called ‘Lucifer’
text: The meteorologists agree: The long hot spell gripping parts of Europe this past week is uncommon.

headline: The Potential and Peril of Giving a Brand a Human Face
text: The actress Stephanie Courtney has quite a weight on her shoulders.

headline: Countering West Coast Pull, by Helping Finance Start-Ups Sell in New York
text: When Jeff Bezos, then a New York hedge fund employee, decided to start Amazon in 1994, he quickly moved to the West Coast. So did Mark Zuckerberg, who moved from Harvard to California in 2004 to find the technology talent and financing needed to build up Facebook.

headline: The Joys, and Woes, of Biking in New York
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: A Season With Dickens, Darwin and Disraeli
text: If you’re having a hard time of it during this sweltering season, just be glad you didn’t live in London in 1858. That summer, the Thames, coursing with the city’s raw sewage, made life intolerable for residents, including members of Parliament, who worked right beside the river’s stench.

headline: A Lack of Resilience
text: To the Editor:

headline: College Legacy Admissions: Affirmative Action for Whites
text: To the Editor:

headline: Joint Taliban-ISIS Attack Kills Dozens, Afghan Officials Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Dozens of civilians and militia forces were killed in northern Afghanistan in what officials on Sunday described as an attack by Taliban fighters teamed up with a commander claiming allegiance to the Islamic State. If true, the open cooperation between the militant groups, which have sometimes fought turf battles in the past, could be further trouble for the struggling Afghan government.

headline: North Korea, Venezuela, Australia: Your Monday Briefing
text: Good morning.

headline: In a Corporate Concert World, an Indie Thrives in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — On a recent tour of the Anthem, his $60 million concert hall under construction, Seth Hurwitz excitedly pointed out the room’s features as they took shape. A movable stage. Angled balconies. An outside terrace with a striking waterfront vista.

headline: Mark White, Texas Governor Who Championed Public Education, Dies at 77
text: Mark White, who as governor of Texas from 1983 to 1987 championed public education laws that limited class sizes, increased teachers’ pay and introduced basic skills tests for high school students, died on Saturday in Houston. He was 77.

headline: Weaning Itself From Elephant Ivory, China Turns to Mammoths
text: NANJING, China — Environmentalists worried about the fate of Africa’s dwindling elephant population cheered when China announced a ban on the sale of commercial ivory last year, but an increasingly popular substitute is raising concerns of its own.

headline: Heng on Democracy in Pakistan
text: Nawaz Sharif, Pakistan’s prime minister, was ousted from office by the Supreme Court over corruption charges, in what appeared to be a fair move. The court sidestepped other officials implicated in the Panama Papers leak that initiated the investigation, leading to accusations that it was pursuing selective justice. The military had cut Sharif’s two previous terms.

headline: Reading, Writing and Refugees
text: Here is a guide to some of the new and forthcoming children’s books about Muslim refugees, ranging from picture books for toddlers and early readers to young adult novels.

headline: Children’s Authors Take On the Refugee Crisis
text: Some of the most shocking images from the crisis in Syria have been photographs of children: the body of a drowned toddler lying on a Turkish beach, the expressionless 5-year-old boy from Aleppo, shellshocked, bloodied and ash-covered, after being pulled from the rubble of a bombed building.

headline: Ty Hardin, Star of ‘Bronco’ Western, Dies at 87
text: Ty Hardin, who roamed the West searching for adventure in the television series “Bronco” in the late 1950s and early ’60s, died on Thursday in Huntington Beach, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Where Dancers Shine Beyond Their Usual Specialties
text: VAIL, Colo. — Since the two galalike signature events of the annual Vail Dance Festival were star-studded, it’s tempting to survey them just by dropping names. After all, on Friday here, Misty Copeland (never more mettlesome) and Marcelo Gomes (richly smoldering) danced Twyla Tharp’s “Sinatra Suite,” followed by Misa Kuranaga (lightly brilliant) and Herman Cornejo (panache itself) in the war horse “Don Quixote” pas de deux.

headline: Cindy Sherman Takes Selfies (as Only She Could) on Instagram
text: Media hacks have Twitter, excitable teenagers have Snapchat and middle managers have LinkedIn, but in the art world, the social network of choice remains Instagram, where all the world’s beauty is gridded into squares.

headline: A Late Outburst Propels the Yankees Over the Indians
text: CLEVELAND — On the occasions when Yankees Manager Joe Girardi calls players into his office, he treats those conversations like privileged communications. No amount of prying or prodding from reporters will prompt him to reveal details of what took place.

headline: Reporters Not Being Pursued in Leak Investigations, Justice Dept. Says
text: WASHINGTON — Rod J. Rosenstein, the deputy attorney general, said on Sunday that the Justice Department was not pursuing reporters as part of its growing number of leak investigations, just two days after he and other department officials had appeared to signal a harsher line toward journalists.

headline: Ordering a Marble Rye
text: Dear Diary:

headline: What Card Dealers Deal
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — If yesterday’s ship-themed puzzle by Patrick Berry had you at sea, today’s gentle week-opener by Kevin Christian will restore your solving self-esteem.

headline: Take the Generic, Patients Are Told. Until They Are Not.
text: This article was written through collaboration between The New York Times and ProPublica, the independent, nonprofit investigative journalism organization.

headline: U.S. Troops Train in Eastern Europe to Echoes of the Cold War
text: NOVO SELO TRAINING RANGE, Bulgaria — After more than a decade spent fighting Islamic insurgents in Iraq and Afghanistan, the United States Army is scrambling to relearn Cold War-era skills to confront potential threats from Russia here in Eastern Europe, territory formerly defended by the Soviet Army.

headline: State Senate Leader John Flanagan Sought Help for Alcohol Problem
text: ALBANY — The Republican leader of the State Senate, John J. Flanagan, announced on Sunday that he had sought help for an alcohol problem after realizing that drinking “was becoming a crutch to deal with pressure I was under related to my responsibilities as majority leader.”

headline: Rwanda President’s Lopsided Re-election Is Seen as a Sign of Oppression
text: KIGALI, Rwanda — The re-election of Paul Kagame, Rwanda’s longtime president, had never been in question. But opponents and rights advocates say his nearly 99 percent margin of victory reflects what they call an oppressive political environment that stifles dissent in the central African nation.

headline: Fox News Suspends Eric Bolling After Report of Lewd Text Messages
text: Fox News suspended Eric Bolling, a longtime host at the network, on Saturday pending an investigation into reports that he sent lewd photographs to three female colleagues via text message.

headline: As Netanyahu Investigators Close In, Some Ask: How Long Can He Hold On?
text: JERUSALEM — Political cartoons depict flames licking at the foundations of the fortresslike household of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Commentators say the noose is tightening around his neck.

headline: Global News Quiz: Trump on the Telephone, Vote in Venezuela, Royal Retirement
text: Did you stay on top of the most important stories last week? Test your knowledge of international events with our quick quiz, recapping major news headlines and featured articles from across the globe. To take the quiz, click on an answer, and the correct response will be revealed after you choose.

headline: No Corrections: August 7, 2017
text: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 7, 2017.

headline: As Kenya’s Vote Nears, Fear That ‘Fake News’ May Fuel Real Bloodshed
text: ELDORET, Kenya — Fake news. Odd plot twists. Tit-for-tat accusations. One candidate calling another “crooked.”

headline: An Awkward and Bittersweet Righting of Doping’s Wrongs
text: LONDON — Tears, so many tears, in sports.

headline: Thousands of Yemeni Forces Target Qaeda Stronghold
text: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — Thousands of Yemeni troops are conducting a clearing operation aimed at driving Qaeda militants from one of their major strongholds in southern Yemen, according to Arab and American security officials.

headline: War-Crimes Prosecutor, Frustrated at U.N. Inaction, Quits Panel on Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For six years, an independent United Nations-appointed panel has documented a litany of war atrocities in Syria that have grown increasingly brazen: torture of prisoners, attacks on hospitals, sexual slavery.

headline: Sprint, Looking to Get Bigger to Survive, Weighs Deal-Making
text: Masayoshi Son, the Japanese telecommunications mogul, has always been known as an inveterate deal maker. But amid a breakneck spree of investing in start-ups, Mr. Son’s most anticipated moves will likely involve an old-line phone service provider: Sprint.

headline: Oil Nations Look to Enforce Production Cuts, and Disney Earnings Are Coming
text: Here’s a look at what’s coming up this week.

headline: Hideki Matsuyama Ties a Course Record to Win the Bridgestone Invitational
text: AKRON, Ohio — As Hideki Matsuyama warmed up Sunday afternoon at the Bridgestone Invitational, his tee shots raised the question: Was that a golf club in his hands or a pellet gun? The way he was spraying balls on the range, Matsuyama figured to struggle to break par.

headline: Trying to Make America a Little Better
text: One of the few practical job-building promises of the Trump presidential campaign — a $1 trillion investment in repairing the nation’s crumbling infrastructure — is turning out to be as hollow as a pothole. Mr. Trump’s vow to push for passage of the plan in the first 100 days of his presidency is sliding off the calendar amid the daily chaos of his incumbency and the Republican obsession with crippling Obamacare.

headline: Jack Rabinovitch, Founder of Canadian Literary Award, Dies at 87
text: Jack Rabinovitch, founder of the pre-eminent prize in Canada for English-language literature, died on Sunday in Toronto. He was 87.

headline: Cuomo to Give Colleges $7 Million for Courses in Prisons
text: ALBANY — Moving ahead with a plan that has drawn criticism from conservatives, the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is awarding more than $7 million in grants to a variety of colleges around the state to offer courses to prisoners.

headline: Quotation of the Day: U.S. Army Dusts Off Cold War-Era Playbook
text: “He’s going to be around for a long time. He’s coup-proof.”

headline: Amid Talk of a 2020 Run, Cuomo Must First Deal With 2018
text: ALBANY — There was a time — call it March — when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s plans for re-election next year seemed almost an afterthought.

headline: ‘Twin Peaks’ Season 3, Episode 13: Starting Position
text: From the beginning, “Twin Peaks” has embedded a clue to unlocking the show in its title. David Lynch and Mark Frost are captivated by dualities, whether they’re giving their characters literal doppelgängers or they’re exploring the extremes of good and evil within humanity as a whole. What’s apparent on the surface counts for little in “Twin Peaks.” A homecoming queen from an upstanding family can turn out to be a drug addicted part-time prostitute, while her father can be a serial sex offender. Just because someone looks pleasantly familiar doesn’t mean they’re okay. Everyone is split.

headline: Betty Cuthbert, Australia’s ‘Golden Girl’ of Track and Field, Dies at 79
text: Betty Cuthbert, Australia’s “golden girl” of track and field, revered for her Olympic gold-medal feats and then her long and spirited struggle against multiple sclerosis, has died in Western Australia. She was 79.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 7, Episode 4: Daenerys Soars, Starks Endure
text: You’re gonna need a bigger ballista.

headline: Dodgers Hold Mets to One Hit and Cap a Three-Game Sweep at Citi Field
text: The loudest ovation Sunday night at Citi Field, during the Mets’ game against the Los Angeles Dodgers, came in the middle of the fourth inning, when the actor Bryan Cranston was shown on the center-field video screen.

headline: Beloit: A Small Wisconsin Town Seeks to Become a Tech Haven
text: Under the impulse of the billionaire Diane Hendricks, Beloit, a small industrial town in Wisconsin, is becoming an attractive location for tech start-ups.

headline: Heat Wave, Mike Pence, Venezuela: Your Monday Briefing
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Darren Daulton, Catcher for the 1993 Pennant-Winning Phillies, Dies at 55
text: Darren Daulton, a three-time All-Star catcher who led a ragtag Philadelphia Phillies team to an improbable pennant in 1993, died on Sunday at his home in Clearwater, Fla. He was 55.

headline: What’s on TV Monday: ‘Vera’ and ‘The Bachelorette’
text: Brenda Blethyn begins the seventh season of “Vera” with a head-scratching mystery. And Rachel Lindsay makes her final decision on “The Bachelorette.”

headline: What Music Do Americans Love the Most? 50 Detailed Fan Maps
text: Detailed maps reveal the contours of American music fandom.

headline: Mysterious Sea Creatures in Australia Chew Up Teenager’s Legs
text: SYDNEY, Australia — Australians tend to roll their eyes when the world obsesses about this country’s dangerous animal kingdom, including its deadly snakes (the deadliest in the world), its tiny and toxic redback spiders, and of course the jellyfish that cause heart attacks.

headline: Inside the Facebook Group Where N.F.L. Wives Share Anxieties and Advice
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The chatter runs the gamut from the practical to the profound, from sharing recipes and finding a home in a new city to dealing with a husband’s growing dementia and applying for medical benefits. Touchy topics like alcoholism, depression and spousal abuse come up, too, mixed in with ideas on what to do with spare time.

headline: Many Politicians Lie. But Trump Has Elevated the Art of Fabrication.
text: WASHINGTON — Whit Ayres, a Republican political consultant here, likes to tell his clients that there are “three keys to credibility.”

headline: Fashion Photography as Social Commentary
text: The second Photo Vogue Festival will continue the debate over what is and isn’t acceptable in fashion photography, with an exhibition that brings together some of the magazine’s most tendentious shoots.

headline: A Rare Round of Diplomacy From North Korea’s Top Diplomat
text: MANILA — A Southeast Asian diplomatic meeting quietly turned into the first real multiparty bargaining session in eight years to tackle North Korea’s nuclear program, as the country’s top diplomat held a rare round of talks with his counterparts from China, South Korea and Russia.

headline: What’s Next for Progressives?
text: For now, at least, the attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act appears dead. Sabotage by a spiteful Trump administration is still a risk, but there is — gasp! — a bipartisan push to limit the damage, with Democrats who want to preserve recent gains allying with Republicans who fear that the public will blame them for declining coverage and rising premiums.

headline: America’s Whiniest ‘Victim’
text: Donald Trump is the reigning king of American victimhood.

headline: The Debt-Ceiling Crisis Is Real
text: Sometime in October, the United States is likely to default on its obligation to pay its bills as they come due, having failed to raise the federal debt ceiling. This will cost the Treasury tens of billions of dollars every year for decades to come in higher interest charges and probably trigger a severe recession.

headline: Germany Joins the Resistance
text: BERLIN — Believe it or not, there was a time when German politicians were cool. There was Helmut Schmidt, the 1970s chancellor, packing up the sails of his boat, sleeves rolled up, his face roughened by the wind, tobacco and the Cold War. But that was then; in the decades since, the country has been run by stolid men and women — and, until lately, we’ve been fine with that. For good reason, Germans have a certain allergy to political charisma.

headline: Trump Embraces a Senseless Immigration Proposal
text: President Trump has endorsed legislation that would slash legal immigration by half, mainly by cutting the number of visas granted to relatives of citizens, while favoring people who speak English and have advanced degrees. The bill, which would do nothing to solve the country’s immigration and economic challenges, is unlikely to become law. The only way to understand Mr. Trump’s vocal support of an obvious turkey is as yet another attempt to energize his dwindling base of right-wing and nativist supporters.

headline: Around the Mediterranean, the Fire This Time
text: Lu Fraili, Sardinia — As my husband and I drove back from dinner one evening last month, we were stunned by something I had never seen in 25 years of summer visits to Sardinia: a corona of flames on the scrub-covered hills above the city of San Teodoro. We feared for the town we’ve known so well, and even for our home here, only about four miles away.

headline: Lenin’s Eco-Warriors
text: NEW HAVEN — Atop a granite cliff in Siberia this past winter, I stood gazing at what became, 100 years ago, the first in the world’s largest system of most protected nature reserves. To my west glistened mile-deep Lake Baikal. To the east rose snowy mountains, including one that reminded me of sharp-cut Half Dome, an icon of America’s Yosemite National Park. I was looking across Barguzinsky Zapovednik, a conservation area protecting more than 600,000 acres so free from human impact that visitors may not enter.

headline: Fashion Photography as Social Commentary
text: When Vogue Italia published a spread by Steven Meisel that was inspired by the deadly Deepwater Horizon oil spill of 2010, it provoked criticism. Bloggers and fashion critics called it tasteless and exploitative, given the devastation to the Gulf of Mexico’s ecosystem. This was neither the first, nor the last time that the publication sparked controversy, and it reinvigorated the debate over what is and isn’t acceptable in fashion photography.

headline: Does Peru Need a Special Prison Just for Ex-Presidents?
text: LIMA, Peru — As Peru prepares for the bicentennial of its independence from Spain in 1821, instead of looking forward with optimism, it is contemplating a dismal political landscape: Four of its former presidents are in jail or fugitives from justice for human rights crimes or corruption. A world record? Probably, but hardly one to celebrate.

headline: A Shingle-Style Beach ‘Cottage’ in the Hamptons
text: An 1877 shingle-style “cottage” with 330 feet of sandy beach 50 feet from the Atlantic Ocean is poised to enter the market at $55 million. The property taxes on the house, on the eastern edge of Wainscott, N.Y., are $13,848 per year.

headline: Tips for Women Traveling Solo, From Dining Out to Hotel Safety

In her more than two decades of frequent solo travel, Ms. Randolph, a former art adviser, says she has encountered her fair share of challenges. “Finding a place to eat and getting plugged into the local scene of your destination isn’t easy when you’re alone,” she said.

headline: Traveling Together? Apps to Help Split (and Pay) the Bills
text: Traveling with a group — friends, extended family, a bachelor party — makes for some of the best summer vacations. It can also make for some of the most complicated vacations when it comes to splitting the costs of dinners, museum admissions, rental homes and cars.

headline: Review: Anna Netrebko Sings Her First ‘Aida’ in Salzburg
text: SALZBURG, Austria — For those of us who admire the soprano Anna Netrebko, it’s been a heady time. During the past few years, as her voice has darkened and swelled, she’s added a flood of new roles by Puccini, Verdi, Tchaikovsky and even Wagner that demand lyric sensitivity but also searing power.

headline: Memphis in Paris: A Classic French Home Filled With Sottsass
text: In the early 1960s — almost two decades before he became the ringleader of the boisterous Memphis collective, a group of some 20 renegade postmodernists — the polymathic Austrian-born designer and architect Ettore Sottsass was touring India when he contracted life-threatening nephritis. Roberto Olivetti, of the Olivetti typewriter company, for whom Sottsass would later dream up a now-iconic cherry-red portable model, paid for his treatment at Stanford University Medical Center in Palo Alto, and during his tedious recovery, Sottsass amused himself by sketching pills stacked vertiginously high, like children’s blocks. When he was released, he wandered north to San Francisco, where he fell in with Allen Ginsberg and Jack Kerouac, a meeting that began his long association with the leading figures of the American counterculture.

headline: For Cosmetics, Let the Buyer Beware
text: When you wash your hair, clean or moisturize your skin, polish your nails, or put on makeup, deodorant or sunscreen, do you ever think about whether the product you’re using may do more harm than good?

headline: Most Mothers Feel Judged, With Families Often the Worst Critics

headline: Trump Company Moves to Protect Brand in Chinese Gambling Hub

headline: Medicare Advantage Spends Less on Care, So Why Is It Costing So Much?
text: The Medicare Advantage program was supposed to save taxpayers money by allowing insurers to offer older Americans private alternatives to Medicare. The plans now cover 19 million people, a third of all those who qualify for Medicare. Enrollee satisfaction is generally high, and studies show that plans offer higher quality than traditional Medicare. But the government pays insurers more than they pay out for patient care — in some years, it turns out, a great deal more.

headline: 4,000 Kilometers, 10 Months: One Australian’s March for Indigenous Rights

headline: Trump’s Stalled Trade Agenda Leaves Industries in the Lurch

headline: How Bad Will It Be If We Hit The Debt Ceiling?
text: The odds of a self-inflicted US debt crisis now look pretty good: hard-line Republicans are eager to hold the economy hostage, Democrats are in no mood to make concessions, and Trump is both spiteful and ignorant. So it looks fairly likely that by October or so there will come a day when the U.S. government stops paying some of its bills, including interest on debt.

headline: The Serial Killer Test: Biases Against Atheists Emerge in Study
text: Most people around the world, whether religious or not, presume that serial killers are more likely to be atheists than believers in any god, suggests a new study, which counters the common assumption that increasingly secular societies are equally tolerant of nonbelievers. Avowed atheists exhibited the same bias in judging sadistic criminals, the study found.

text: They hitchhike across Europe, instantly recognizable in the wide-bottomed, corduroy trousers, white shirts and colored jackets that identify them as bricklayers, bakers, carpenters, stonemasons and roofers.

headline: Macron’s Honeymoon Comes to a Halt

headline: Five Nights of New Music, From Gentle to Terrifying
text: Along with the master provocateur John Cage, Earle Brown (1926-2002) was a member of the mid-20th-century composers’ collective known as the New York School. Yet while Cage was scabrous about the value of recorded music, preferring to issue books that could accompany his written scores, Brown dove with gusto into the world of LP production, releasing 18 experimental titles on his Contemporary Sound Series, from 1960 to 1973. (The complete set has been reissued on CD by the Wergo label over the last decade.)

headline: Noah Syndergaard’s ‘Game of Thrones’ Cameo Ends in Fiery Death
text: It can be hard to compare the relative strengths of competing mythologies, but on this week’s episode of HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” it appeared that a Norse god could hold his own against a horde of Dothraki warriors, but was no match for a full-grown dragon.

headline: Democrats Demand Transparency for Trump’s Deregulation Teams

headline: Dirty Cocktails Without the Pits
text: Yes, you could add a splash of the liquid from a jar of olives to your martini. Or you could pop open a bottle of olive juice formulated for cocktails by Gaea, a Greek food company that sells fine olive oils. The juices are made using brines left over from the company’s olive and oil production. Green olive juice is for use with gin. Brine from pimento-stuffed olives is designated for vodka, and it has a nice little kick: Gaea Dirty Martini Juice, $2.49 for 8.5 ounces, gaeaus.com.

headline: Crab Cakes Fresh From Maryland
text: Cameron’s, a Maryland seafood company that has specialized in blue crabs and crab cakes since 1985, has started shipping its products fresh nationwide. The crab cakes, generous with chunks of snowy meat, require a simple sauté in butter. They are a hefty eight ounces each and can easily be divided into smaller portions. The company also sells luxurious cream of crab soup, whole steamed crabs, king crab legs, jumbo lump crab meat, shrimp and other seafood: Crab cakes, $9.99 each for four ounces, $19.99 each for eight ounces; cream of crab soup, $19.99 for one quart, cameronsseafood.com.

headline: A Dark and Sweet Cherry for the Dog Days of Summer
text: These dark, glossy cherries are firm and sweetly complex. Several varieties are grown in Oregon at high altitudes, handpicked and shipped by air. Because the cherries are tree-ripened, the season is later, with some available until the end of August: $89.95 for a five-pound box, including shipping, Hood River Cherry Company, 800-709-4722, hrcherrycompany.com.

headline: Women Without Options and Spoiled for Choice

headline: Zuma to Face No-Confidence Vote, This Time by Secret Ballot
text: CAPE TOWN — Over his eight increasingly embattled years in power, President Jacob Zuma of South Africa has fended off five parliamentary no-confidence motions that would have forced him from office. On Tuesday, he is to face another, with a difference: Lawmakers will vote anonymously.

text: BERLIN — Martin Roth, the first non-Briton to lead the venerable Victoria and Albert Museum in London, and a pathbreaking curator in Britain, his native Germany and around the world, died on Sunday in Berlin. He was 62.

The aprons are made of sturdy yet lightweight Turkish denim with a waxy stain-resistant coating. Each is named for a different culinary personality, and some of them have a charitable donation built into the price: Art of Simplicity by Sosa, $88 to $98, aosbysosa.com.

headline: Florence Pugh, a Woman on the Verge
text: The actress Florence Pugh’s performance in William Oldroyd’s arresting film “Lady Macbeth” has won her praise (and prizes) on the festival circuit this year. “There’s a scene toward the end that is quite shocking,” says the 21-year-old Brit, who plays the protagonist, Katherine. “Some people have gotten up and left, and to me, that’s so exciting because we have achieved the ultimate. We have affected you so much that you can’t sit and watch it anymore.”

headline: Bracing Ice Cream Flavors From Scandinavia
text: Would some consider rye-and-gooseberry ice cream a tasty treat or not? For me, it’s an earthy, nutty delight. A tart-sweet golden sorbet, made from sea buckthorn berries and carrots, and a richly herbal sorrel ice cream are the other Scandinavian flavors at the new Great Northern Creamery, a cart tucked near the herb garden in the Great Northern Food Hall. Fear not if your tastes are more conventional. Chocolate and buttermilk ice creams and a raspberry sorbet are also available by the scoop or inside a warm, toasted brioche: Great Northern Food Hall, Grand Central Terminal, 89 East 42nd Street, 646-568-4020, greatnorthernfood.com.

headline: $78,000 of Debt for a Harvard Theater Degree
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — Twelve years after finishing Harvard’s graduate theater program, Katierose Donohue still pays almost as much in student loans each month — about $650 — as for her share of the rent in Los Angeles. She recently stopped hosting her monthly sketch comedy show, “Ma’am,” because she didn’t always break even on her $200 budget. She’s now working side jobs as a dog walker and a social media copywriter, after past gigs serving at Starbucks and handing out free cigarettes for Camel.

headline: Where Salmon Is the Lure
text: For three weeks every July, Alaskans crowd the beaches at Kenai to catch their free share of sockeye salmon.

headline: Free Alaskan Salmon: Just Bring a Net and Expect a Crowd
text: KENAI, Alaska — Wenceslous Fru, a physician assistant from Anchorage, stood on the sandy shore of the Kenai River and imagined the dinner he would put together once he felt the jostle of a salmon in his long-handled dip net. He would make it the way they do back home in Cameroon, splitting it down the belly and opening it like a book, rubbing it with ginger, garlic and spices, and then slipping it under the broiler.

headline: Ernst Zündel, Holocaust Denier Tried for Spreading His Message, Dies at 78

headline: Santa Monica Symphony Roiled by Conservative Guest Conductor

Mr. Lamell, music director of the orchestra, invited the conservative talk show host and columnist Dennis Prager as guest conductor for the event.

headline: Newport Jazz Festival Begins a New Era, With History as a Guide

headline: States Have Already Passed Almost Twice as Many Immigration Laws as Last Year
text: When Republicans in Texas passed a ban on so-called “sanctuary city” policies this spring, they appeared to be feeding on the momentum created by Donald J. Trump, who had made illegal immigration a centerpiece of his campaign. They were not alone. State lawmakers across the country are addressing issues created by immigration.

headline: The Taylor Swift Groping Trial, Day 1: Still No Jury

headline: Walmart Heirs Snap Up Rapha, the British Bikewear Brand

headline: Avoiding the Trap of Immigration Porn
text: LOS ANGELES — See if you can ride along with some agents from Immigration and Customs Enforcement rounding up Latino immigrants, the photo editor tells the photographer. Go capture a group of brown-skinned innocents being led away in cuffs. And if one of the ICE agents is also Latino, the editor adds, so much the better.

headline: Award-Winning Marmalades to Gift or Devour
text: Gregory Benjamin Conocchioli, 63, has pursued several careers, but his latest was born from a wedding gift. Five years ago, he made 150 jars of preserves for his niece’s wedding, and afterward he received requests for more. So Mr. Conocchioli rented a church kitchen in his village, Carversville, Pa., and went into business. For the past three years, his marmalades and preserves have won medals in the World’s Original Marmalade Awards in Cumbria, England. Orange-almond-apricot and citrus-blend marmalades are just two of the outstanding choices: Gregory Benjamin Artisan Preserves and Marmalades, $9 to $16.50, preservesandmarmalade.com.

headline: Sessions Scolds Chicago for Suing Over ‘Sanctuary Cities’ Threat
text: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel sued the Justice Department on Monday over President Trump’s threat to cut off federal grants for so-called sanctuary cities like Chicago, calling it an attack against public safety and the city’s conscience.

headline: For Shakespeare & Company’s Tina Packer, a Last Romance
text: In 1971, Tina Packer, then a classically trained English actress, persuaded the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art to let her direct Shakespeare’s “Measure for Measure.” Then she directed “The Winter’s Tale,” then “Hamlet.”

headline: Q. and A.: ‘Game of Thrones’ Actor Nikolaj Coster-Waldau on Jaime Lannister’s Charge
text: On this week’s episode of “Game of Thrones,” for the first time, we were faced with a battle in which it was possible to root for both sides. When Jaime Lannister (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) started to charge a distracted Daenerys Targaryen, we, too, were as torn as Tyrion. Don’t we want the Kingslayer to get a chance to save the day? Don’t we want Dany to turn her fortunes around and get a win?

headline: Rapid Malaria Tests Work, but With Unexpected Drawbacks

headline: Is the Best Pedicure in New York Worth $85?

Plop down, let someone soak and exfoliate and massage and moisturize your feet, and all that is asked of you is to stare into space, read that week’s tabloid or, in my case, gently stalk your high school crush’s wife on Instagram. It’s a respite, a meditation, a way for me to incorporate some color into my wardrobe.

headline: Trump Threatens ‘Fire and Fury’ Against North Korea if It Endangers U.S.
